description_html:
This gallery contains the images of America's President and Vice President from 2017 to the present, Donald Trump and Mike Pence. It also includes images of Mitch McConnell, the Senate Majority Leader 2015-present, and Nancy Pelosi, the Speaker of the House of Representatives 2019-present.

All of these images share a considerable amount of Green — which indicates all of these people are coldly decisive. This is natural because a career in politics requires a certain degree of insensitivity — a thick skin — regardless of which side a person is on.

The Red and Yellow in Donald's image make his the warmest, and it stands in contrast to the Green and Blue in Mike's and Nancy's image. The massive amount of Green in Mitch's image makes his image stand out the most from the others in this group. Of course, being based on Jungian archetypes, these images do not take into account political affiliations, which in 2020 are stronger than ever and hence override these hidden, abstract similarities.
story_html:
Donald and Mike: The Executive Team

These two images are fairly colorful, showing that Donald Trump and Mike Pence have fairly moderate preferences. It's easy to see how they could work well together, and indeed, if there is any conflict between them it is private and not public.

Donald, Mike, Mitch, and Nancy: The Team

Mitch has an extreme personality and looks out of place here, but these appearances are deceiving. In reality, it is Nancy who is the outlier in this group.

Politics in America in 2020 is rife with severely toxic partisanship. This causes Mitch to readily align with his Republican colleagues Donald and Mike, while Nancy, the only Democrat in the group, is of forced to be an outsider.

Big Five OCEAN Results

Following are how — based on my informed opinion — Donald and Mike would score on Lewis Goldberg's 300-item open source questionnaire. These items can be found at the International Personality Item Pool.

image_list.story_html:
This story comes from the book Visualizing Politicians' Personalities, 2019 Incumbents and Candidates by Tom W. Hartung, © 2019, all rights reserved.

THIS IMAGE OF THE PERSONALITY OF DONALD TRUMP expresses his warmth and pragmatism.

Donald’s warmth is evident in the way his speeches at his rallies make people emotional. There are numerous reports of the crowds at his rallies engaging in irrational chants such as Lock her up when there is no crime and Send her back when there is no back.

An example of Donald’s realism is when he pulled the country out of the Paris Agreement on climate change. Doing this showed he gives precedence to short-term goals and things he can see, rather than prioritizing things such as climate change, which requires looking at the long term and understanding models and other ideas that elude the senses.

There is considerably more content about Donald, including a look at how he and Steve Bannon worked together to win the election, in the Bonus Profile chapter. [To be published online soon!]

For more about Donald Trump, see the story about Populist Politicians on ArtsyVisions.com.

THE PROFILE FOR THIS IMAGE IS BASED ON a profile I developed shortly before I read Ron Chernow's biography of Alexander Hamilton and decided to start using more biographies, memoirs, and the like. I created the profile with Laura Haynes, a psychologist friend, and it is based on Donald’s public persona.

Since creating the profile I have read several books about Donald. These books include The Hill to Die On by Jake Sherman and Anna Palmer, Devils Bargain by Joshua Green, How Trump Won by Joel Pollack and Larry Schweikart, and both Fire and Fury, and Siege by Michael Wolff.

Having read all those books, and having read about Donald in the news daily, I am confident this profile is accurate. Moreover, rest assured that if I wasn't confident in it, I would not hesitate to re-do it!

image_list.story_html:
This story comes from the book Visualizing Politicians' Personalities, 2019 Incumbents and Candidates by Tom W. Hartung, © 2019, all rights reserved.

THIS IMAGE OF THE PERSONALITY OF MIKE PENCE shows he is outgoing and able to keep his cool in difficult situations. The variety of colors show his preferences are moderate, but the overall coolness in the portrait shows he is a stubborn defender of his beliefs.

In her book Pence, The Path to Power, Andrea Neal relates that in the late 1980s through the 1990s, before Mike was elected to public office, he hosted a series of conservative talk radio shows. She writes that his show on the statewide Network Indiana in 1994 ran in the time slot just before Rush Limbaugh’s program aired. Mike wanted to be like Limbaugh but without the combativeness [p. 76]. Later Mike would call himself Rush Limbaugh on decaf [p. 76].

Andrea Neal continues, In contrast to Limbaugh ... Pence was deliberate in trying to understand the perspective of callers and guests on the other side. [p. 78]. Quoting Mike, she describes how his faith was the reason he wanted to differentiate himself from Rush. My obligation first as a Christian is to try to respect that person.... If you can't disagree and maintain some civility, then forget democracy [p. 78].

No image of Rush Limbaugh’s personality is currently available, but it is reasonable to suspect he is more stubborn than most people so an image of his personality could look more like Mitch McConnell’s or Steve Bannon’s bichromatic spiritual portraits, and less like Mike’s colorful portrait above.

AS GOVERNOR OF INDIANA IN 2015, MIKE’S IDEOLOGY came face-to-face with cold hard reality when he signed Indiana Senate Bill 101, Indiana’s Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), on March 26. Andrea Neal opens Chapter 13, entitled Crisis at the Capitol, of her book with Mike defending the bill on the show This Week With George Stephanopoulos.

In her book Andrea Neal describes Mike as deeply religious. She writes that during his primary campaign for the House of Representatives in 2000, he referred to himself publicly as ‘a Christian, conservative, and Republican in that order’ . The author writes this is a line he would recite in every campaign thereafter [p. 112].

The RFRA bill stoked outrage as many perceived it as condoning discrimination against LGBT individuals. This flew in the face of the claim made by many of the state’s residents that There are no kinder, more generous, more welcoming people than Hoosiers, and Hoosiers don't believe in discrimination [p. 176].

Andrea Neal writes of how, five days after Mike signed the bill, protests over it were forcing him and the legislators behind it to reconsider its provisions. On March 31, the Indianapolis Star ran a full-page editorial on page one under the headline ‘FIX THIS NOW.’... With or without the newspaper's urging, a fix had become inevitable [p. 186].

Initially proud of the bill, Mike and the Indiana legislators saw from the resulting protests that it was severely damaging the state’s reputation. After meetings between key legislators, business and sports leaders, and members of the governor's staff [p. 186] a supplemental bill, Senate Bill 50, was pushed through the state’s senate and house right away. Andrea Neal writes Pence signed Senate Bill 50 into law that afternoon – on April 2nd, 2015 – and as a result, the threats of economic sanctions died out quickly [p. 187].

Mike is open to listening to and talking with people who disagree with him, but the RFRA crisis shows how his commitment to his religion can blind him to the real-world effects of legislation that does not adequately take other citizens’ points-of-view into account.

THE PROFILE FOR THIS IMAGE IS BASED ON the book Pence, The Path to Power, by Andrea Neal, 2018.

image_list.story_html:
This story comes from the book Visualizing Politicians' Personalities, 2019 Incumbents and Candidates by Tom W. Hartung, © 2019, all rights reserved.

THIS IMAGE OF THE PERSONALITY OF NANCY PELOSI shows she is committed and determined, yet open to ideas that are in line with her principles. The variety of colors shows she is versatile, with the Blue representing her religious and political ideals, and the Green and Red representing a tendency to be decisive.

In his book Woman of the House, The Rise of Nancy Pelosi, Vincent Bzdek tells of how Nancy grew up in Baltimore, Maryland going to Catholic school at the Institute of Notre Dame. Upon graduation from there she went to Trinity College, a Roman Catholic University in Washington, D.C., now known as Trinity Washington University. From an early age religious ideals have formed the foundation of Nancy’s idealism.

Despite her religious foundation, Nancy is pro-choice. In Chapter 2 of his book, entitled The Social Gospel, Vincent Bzdek explains how she reconciles her religious and political ideals with respect to this persistently contentious issue. The key is the the primacy of conscience argument, which insists that a person can't go against what her conscience tells her to do [p. 41, emphasis in original].

On less contentious issues, Vincent Bzdek says Nancy practices the politics of consensus. He tells of how her work is often a balancing act they have to contend with, constantly calibrating what she calls ‘the three Cs:’ Conscience, the Constitution, and Constituents. The author parenthetically mentions a fourth C is becoming increasingly important: Cash [p. 141].

THE COLORS IN NANCY’S SPIRITUAL PORTRAIT REPRESENT her very well-balanced tendencies, which help her perform this balancing act [p. 141].

Although slight, Nancy’s greatest tendency is to be logical. An ability to keep things logically organized is a huge benefit to any campaign. In Chapter 4, entitled Back in the Game, Vincent Bzdek quotes Nancy’s brother – known as Tommy III – as saying his sister is a great organizer and that organizing is her forte [p. 87].

Fundraising also takes people skills, and Nancy finds it natural to balance her rationality with compassion. Vincent Bzdek writes of a senior Democratic staff member who acknowledged Nancy‘s mechanistic, organizational way of looking at politics, then said she also has an incredibly empathetic way of looking at policy [p. 95].

What makes Nancy unique in today’s political arena is not seen in this image, but deserves mention. In Chapter 1, entitled The Family Vocation, Vincent Bzdek writes of Nancy’s father, Thomas D’Alesandro, Jr. who served 22 consecutive terms in public office [p. 20], winning elections to a series of offices such as state delegate, U.S. congressman, and mayor of Baltimore. The author quotes Nancy as saying that, when she and her brothers where growing up, their whole lives were politics and when people entered the house, it was always campaign time [p. 19].

Nancy’s childhood experiences, and the lessons she learned from her politically successful father, certainly contributed to her rise to Speaker of the House in 2007. What is less obvious – until now – is how her determined, yet otherwise balanced temperament also gives her the drive and flexibility to meet the demands and expectations of her constituents and peers as she continues to serve in the House of Representatives.

THE PROFILE FOR THIS IMAGE IS BASED ON the book Woman of the House, The Rise of Nancy Pelosi, by Vincent Bzdek, 2008.
